author: schone_wizard
content: can anyone shed some light on the next steps from here, how we're going to get to Phase 1?

author: schone_wizard
content: what's currently in the works already, what needs to be reasearched still? etc

author: djrtwo
content:
Eth2 call this thursday -- https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-pm/issues/196
and then we'll take a break on the 31st

author: djrtwo
content:
Specs are being vetted and refined while some simulation and other R&D work is ongoing. 

In January, we'll be working with client teams to shift some resources from phase 0 hardening/maintenance to building out sharding and merge. In the first half of the year, this will likely be somewhere between R&D and production engineering. Very much expect there to be a feedback loop between engineers and the specification, as we saw in Phase 0.

eth1<->eth2 merge work is also ongoing. There have been a few ethresearch posts showing hte direction here and there is active work on modding production clients to put together a testnet

author: schone_wizard
content: thank you for that explanation <@!291925846556540928> !

author: schone_wizard
content: looking forward to trying out the testnet(s)

author: schone_wizard
content: Also I haven't heard the end of the conversation on the last call about Pyrmont's fate, but I wanted to throw in a thought about it

author: schone_wizard
content: I think it's very valuable to have a testnet, that is fast forward by about a month of mainnet which matches mainnet completely.  For me, I use that as a canary deployment ground, where any new version of the client that is announced, I first deploy to Pyrmont, give it about a week of checking if I encounter any errors with my setup, and only then deploy that version to my mainnet config

author: djrtwo
content: we discussed this a bit on the last public call. Pyrmont will remain as is at least through January. In the new year, we'll discuss if there are any good options to ensure the public testnet is a bit more stable, but if Pyrmont remains stable, I don't see us messing with it soon

author: djrtwo
content: and yes, we'll certainly use it to deploy any upgrades before mainnet

author: djrtwo
content: is that what you mean by "fast forward"?

author: schone_wizard
content: what I mean is that if for some reason there is any hiccup in the protocol that we haven't foreseen like some overflow or anything really, we would benefit from having a chain that is 1 month older in time than mainnet.  Like knowing a comet is about to hit you and what its implications are 1 month before it really hits you
